reviewText: If nothing else, 'Tron Legacy' is Sci-Fi eye-candy.  Of course 'Tron Legacy' has some visual appeal that immediately hooks in the audience.  There are discuses which are thrown as weapons in stadium duels between man and machine, artificial crowd cheering, and vehicles that ride in Matrix-like slow-motion arcs that splash wild neon colors in high-tech chase scenes.There's a trade off that takes place between the original Tron and the sequel, 'Tron Legacy'.  And judging both entities is really a matter of separating the story from the special effects.  (Although taking a movie apart in not an entirely fair way to judge a movie.)Call me old-fashioned.  Call me clueless, but, while I love how the new visuals' striking appeal, and I really enjoyed how they linked time together by having Flynn's son visit his father's old arcade after he mysteriously disappeared from his Fortune 500 company (as well as rebooting the sequel by having Jeff Bridges and Bruce Boxleitner on the screen) the pregnant pauses for narrative and a too-often pensive story-line take away the excitement and urgency found in the primitive original.Further that with more stagnant and less compelling chase sequences in between, and I thought much of the magic was lost.  The fights in the inner space bar seem lame and familiar--especially if you consider the original 'Star Wars' as the standard.  Chris Pine or Channing Tatum could just have easily taken the part of Sam Flynn (Garrett Hedlund).  This young protagonist, along with a few others were far from a stellar cast, except for Bridges who could play his character with the vitality and looks easily reminiscent of his younger performance--alongside with his aging counterpart, a Zen recluse (a captive to his own technology) and his nemesis/alter ego (Clu).  Olivia Wilde as the heroine, Quorra, doesn't do much for the proceedings either.  Bruce Boxleitner is merely a token memory of the original.I truly remember the original 'Tron' back in the early eighties.  It transported me to a place I had never been before.  In college video games had invigorated our recreation time with "Donkey Kong," "Pac-Man," and "Centipede," which gave us study breaks and a hefty escape from the pressures of college.  Tron delivered us into that same world in a sustaining way by combining a convincing mix of arcade life and real life.  The visuals and the world created there were both unique and mesmerizing.  By the time the protagonist was brought back to life outside the game, I felt I had been gone a long time.'Tron Legacy' remains worthy as a minor arcade, a nice milestone party, and a bit of memory filing experience--not unlike a thirty year high school reunion, but, in the end, the film is a forgettable ride that might be worth taking only once.

reviewText: I have not seen the original `Tron' film.  Maybe that was a bad way to walk into this film, and then again maybe it was the best way.  My eyes were not blinded by the blindfold of nostalgia and I was able to judge the film based on its own merits and not those created by its predecessor.  And then again, some will balk that movies within a series need to be seen and judged within that series because some if not most is lost on eyes not familiar with the origins of the film.I don't see `Tron' as being in that boat since I could follow this film rather easily and so I don't think anything at all was lost of these virgin eyes.`Tron: Legacy' tells the story of a young man named Sam who is haunted by the disappearance of his father.  His father, Kevin Flynn, was a computer genius who created a cyber-universe of sorts and then suddenly vanished after leaving the lingering promise to take his son to that world.  His son, now all grown up, is a rebel of sorts; a young man swimming in the wealth his father left behind who has no desire to run his father's company but takes it upon himself to sabotage their efforts if he sees them conflicting with what he perceives would have been his father's wishes.  After a mysterious `page' comes through from his father's old office, Sam ventures into the unknown as he is sucked into the world behind the screen, the world his father created but that has now become trapped in the chaos surrounding the enthronement of Kevin's own creation; Clu.  Clu is the evil doppelganger of Kevin Flynn, a dangerous force determined to travel into the real world.  The only way that he can do that is to enter the portal using a special disc resting on Kevin's back.  Kevin has thus been in hiding, dwelling in the outskirts of The Grid with a young woman, a miracle of sorts, who has proved to be his guardian angel.  Sam now has to help his father defeat Clu before the rest of the world suffers at his tyranny.To say that this film is hollow would be an understatement.  There really isn't any depth at play here.  That doesn't mean that the film isn't fun, because it excels in that department.  In fact, the film is a visual feast and I must admit to being blindsided by that.  When I initially saw the trailer for the film I was unimpressed.  The dark color palate just seemed so monotonous and I was expecting to be bored by the film's framing, but what I found was rather stellar.  The scenes are expertly framed.  The cinematography is exciting and bold and the blacks and bright lights complement each other flawlessly.The acting is decent.  Olivia Wilde has never looked better (and I mirror the sentiments that that shot of her lounging on the couch is THE still of the year) but she doesn't do much.  Bridges phones it in, Sheen oversells it (but he's fun) and Hedlund just looks happy to be there (but he has talent, it's just not on display here).  The script is lazy and formulaic (and there are some plot points that are never thought through fully, especially concerning Tron himself) and really is nothing but an excuse for digital violence, but that is the best part of the film and the real reason to watch.Your eyes will be happy you invited them to this party.

reviewText: First of all, you need to know that I very much enjoyedTron (20th Anniversary Collector's Edition)when it came out back in 1982 - I think I saw it three times in two days when I first saw it (this was in the days before everyone had video players), and I have seen it several times since. Plus, it's rated PG - totally watchable!What I can tell you without revealing anything about the storyline is that watching the movie was more of an overall experience for the senses than just an action movie.  There were fantastic effects, but the effects did not overwhelm or drive the story, and the techno-music from Daft Punk was a perfect match to the digital world of the web.  TRON: Legacy wasn't at all like the somewhat unsatisfying experience I had with Star Wars III - which was a major dose of digital candy with little else to offer.Anyway, TRON: Legacy had an interesting premis stemming from TRON (1982), had many interesting connections to that older film if you know what to look for, e.g., Dumont's garage, "That is a big door", etc.  Jeff Bridges was fantastic, the special effects were gripping, the action was engaging, and the acting was quite good.  I think that this film was better or at least on par with other good recent films I've seen, e.g., Avatar, Sherlock Holmes, etc.  It's not a non-stop adrenaline rush, but it's a good mix of action, thoughtfulness, great effects, and memorable characters.This is definitely a 5-star show for sci-fi fans, and a 4-star offering for action adventure fans. reviewText: I was never that excited about Tron: Legacy, having not seen the original movie, but the visual style got me interested. Well, that and Olivia Wilde looking damn good in all the ads I'd seen. But watching Tron: Evolution was a complete chore, despite me being wide awake and not having any distractions. This movie was cold, had all the action in the first half of the movie, had one whole character with personality, and relied way too much on the incredible special effects. Just think about the Star Wars prequels, only nowhere near as bad, and that's what Tron: Legacy is. I think this movie will only appeal to hardcore fans of the original, who've been waiting so long for the sequel, or people who will like anything sci-fi because they don't know any better.The movie starts out with Sam Flynn, son of Kevin Flynn, the original Tron's main character. Kevin built a computer program that was essentially its own world, but disappeared one day, never to be seen again. After causing a little bit of over-dramatic havoc with the company his dad ran, Sam goes into Kevin's old arcade, and stumbles upon an old computer, and enters the program. The world looks like a high-tech night club, complete with a rockin' soundtrack to go along with it, but it's not all fun. Immediately, Sam is thrown into dangerous games, where you can be 'derezzed' (the program's equivalent of death), whether you're a real person or AI. After he gets saved by the lovely Quorra, Sam meets his dad for the first time in years, where everything's revealed about the world, and how they can get out into the real world again.If the plot summary sounds good to you, well, then by all means rent the movie. But there are too many problems that keep it from being the hit that it wanted to be. First up, the characters are dull. Aside from Kevin Flynn, I didn't care for any of these characters. Well, aside from Quorra of course, but that's just because she was so dang pretty. Sam is plain, all the bad guys are as generic as you can be and not threatening, emoting mostly with scowls, and yelling here and there, and it's hard to connect with them. Granted, there were some good father-son moments, but that was all thanks to Jeff Bridges' acting, where it always came off as sincere. I liked the touch of having Kevin use some outdated slang words from the 80s, but I couldn't help thinking that I was seeing The Dude instead of Kevin Flynn in some parts. The other huge problem is that all the action is thrown into the first half of the movie: a big chase, light cycle races, disc fights, etc. These were all really cool scenes, and not getting anything even equal to those scenes for the climax was a huge letdown. Almost as bad is the lack of humor that isn't coming out of Jeff Bridges' mouth. I wasn't expecting a comedy, but for god's sake, this movie could almost pass off as a sci-fi drama instead of a sci-fi action movie. Before and after the light cycle and disc fight scenes, I was literally falling asleep thanks to the poor pacing. As incredible as the visuals and art direction were, which is the reason I'm still thinking about this movie 2 months after watching it, I don't know if I'll ever buy it and watch it much because of how boring it was. This is one of those movies I'd have just to skip to my favorite scenes, then throw back on the shelf for x months.As for the blu-ray itself, it's absolutely perfect. Flawless picture and audio. If there's any one movie out there to show off your new tv and sound system with, it's definitely this one. And if you have a 3D tv, go with the 3D version of the movie, because it's one of the few 3D blu-rays that really uses the technology as it was meant to be. I have zero complaints in these categories. The special features are loaded as well, but the main thing you'll want to watch is the Flynn Lives material. It covers the marketing campaign that got all the hardcore fans hyped.Like I just mentioned, I'm still thinking about this movie 2 months later, but it's all because of the visuals and soundtrack...and Olivia Wilde. There's nothing special about Tron: Legacy as far as the story or characters go, and it has a couple of scenes that are downright embarrassing to watch (Michael Sheen's odd dance bit comes to mind immediately). But the look of the movie is so beautiful that I have to recommend it because of that. Maybe go with The Art of Tron art book instead, and save yourself some boredom.

reviewText: Before I begin, I will tell you that I have never seen the original Tron--nor do I have any desire to. I've seen clips and I do not find it visually appealing. I understand the gist of the plot and the character's involved and know enough to understand the references in Tron: Legacy. When I think of 3D, I think of objects flying out of the screen and feeling like I could reach out my hand and touch them. With Tron: Legacy, there was so much potential here. A disc flying out, programs disintegrating in front of you..etc etc. There were moments where it felt like my eyes were crossed, more than anything. I don't doubt that certain scenes like the lightcycle grid and disc wars, the 3D really enhanced them, but I'm not sure it was worth the extra four bucks. The second time, I saw it in regular 2D and walked away feeling like the special effects were just as amazing. Now there were a couple of parts in 2D where things looked almost fake and you can tell that they were supposed to be 3D but not so much that it bothers you. The best part about the 3D experience was the trailers you saw before the movie, especially the intro for the Real 3D.There were a couple of things that annoyed me. For one, Kevin Flynn's overuse of 'man', 'radical', etc etc. The number of Star Wars references was another thing. The great purge of the ISOs...sounds like order 66 ie, the great jedi purge. During the dogfight scene, I expected Kevin to tell Sam not to get cocky. Perhaps I only see them that way because Star Wars is my geekdom, but obviously I was able to make connections.I do wish there had been greater detail about how Kevin created this new grid and how he was able to manifest a living space in the outlands. But that's not something that makes the movie bad for me. It just makes me thirst for more of the universe.I feel like there are very subtly placed possibilities for a continuation of the franchise and I have mixed feelings about that. It would be nice for a film to actually have an final ending, but at the same time, I feel like there is a lot of room to flesh this out and maybe answer those questions that others have asked.As far as acting goes, I think Garrett Hedlund did a good job in his role. I liked the character Quorra and would love to see her developed further.I will anxiously await this movie to be put out on blu-ray.

reviewText: TRON: Legacy is the first film Disney has made in my 30-something year history that can be solidly labelled as being for adults. The statement that it has not an idea in its head is one only someone ridiculously ignorant of the film or of the real-world situation it is paralleling can make. reviewText: I saw Tron: Legacy (2010) on the big screen on opening day a few weeks ago. The visual architecture of the film is simply breathtaking. The music and sound of the film is deep, powerful, and incredible. Daft Punk created an incredible score for this film, worthy of checking out on its own. I'm absolutely amazed at how this digital world was imagined and created. Director Joseph Kosinski, with his education and background in architecture, was clearly the brilliant Architect of the Tron: Legacy world in his directorial debut. I can't believe Kosinski was trusted with this massive film in his first outing as a director. There are scenes that are simply EPIC and will live on forever in cinematic history. I had goosebumps and chills at times in anticipation from the visuals and music. But as an overall film, Tron: Legacy didn't quite live up to my high expectations from watching the trailers over the last year. It's a good film...very much worthy of seeing on the big screen for its spectacle and digital wonderland. But beyond its eye- and aural-candy, the movie felt a bit empty. It tried so hard to have the soul of a great film. But like the lesson it tries to teach through its story, it's imperfection that is perfect...not perfection. Perfection is actually imperfect. And Tron: Legacy tries to be a little too perfect.I give Tron:Legacy 3.5 stars out of 5. It's definitely entertaining in many ways, as I mentioned above. The marketing for the film worked for me, because I've been anticipating this film for over a year and I just had to see it in the theater opening day...even though I was never a fan of the original film. I think the biggest flaws in the movie are the writing, acting, and directing. Neither fulfill on the promise that seemed possible in the trailers for this sequel to the original Tron (1982). Jeff Bridges and Garrett Hedlund, as father and son, do their best to bring life to the story and the relationship between them. But it's all just too cold and empty. Both actors spurt out blips and blurbs but do nothing to tie what their saying to anything. Hedlund's lines especially are just filled with cheap one-line bits, that lose their humor after awhile.Again, it's like the film is so "perfectly" scripted that it doesn't allow for emotional imperfection to be portrayed on the big screen. I don't really buy into the stories of the two main characters or their relationship. Hedlund, as Sam Flynn, doesn't convey any emotion with his father Kevin (Jeff Bridges). His father's been missing for years and years and yet there is no release of the incredible tension and emotion that one would think would be present between them. They just kind of waive off all those years and move on instantly, because that get's us into more visual effects scenes. The story worked in the first act of the film, where it attempts to develop a relationship between father and son, but midway through the plot just fell apart. It became all about the chase and the action between the good guys and the bad guys. It fell into typical Hollywood blockbuster action and special effects mode with a hollow center.As an Architect myself, I've spent much of my life looking at "perfect" photos of buildings, spaces, and landscapes. And for many years, I never paid attention to what was missing in all those photos. Instead, I always oohed and awed over the building's structure, materials, details, etc. I'd notice the furniture, the light fixtures, the plants, the artwork, the door hardware, and all the things that go into creating architecture. What was missing? People. People are imperfect...so they are almost always left out of architectural photos. But people are who use architecture. People are who design and build and enjoy the buildings and spaces that we architects create. "The Grid" in the world of Tron feels more like an architecture photo to me than a movie. I oohed and awed while I looked at Tron's incredible structures, materials, and details. But after being satisfied as an Architect, I became dissatisfied as a Cinephile and a person. Movies ultimately are about people and their stories and their emotions and their imperfections. Architecture is an incredible art and I love being an Architect, creating things from nothing but my imagination. But it's people who are important both on the screen, behind the screen, and in front of the screen. And it's our stories that keep us interested in the screen. I think Director/Architect Joseph Kosinski naively got lost in creating buildings, spaces, and the world of Tron, like most architects would, and didn't spend enough time creating the people, characters and emotions to inhabit that incredible world. I'll be curious to see what he creates next time.
summary: Visually and Acoustically Stunning, But Lacking a Soul

reviewText: I remember seeing the original Tron back in 1982 and thought it was a lot of fun. Back then the film just came out with little fanfare prior to its release. Nowadays every film comes out with an entire economy of junk and press months, sometimes years, ahead of it. Generally nothing winds up satisfying expectations with all this hoopla in advance. Never mind the current addiction to cynicism everyone seems to have. Nothing is good. Everything is lame. Mockery on everything is the language of the day. Ugh. How did we become so jaded? I am sad at how much vitriol is wasted on films just meant to be enjoyed. Scathing reviews as if people were just robbed of all their earthly possessions.For me the original Tron sits firmly alongside fun childhood films like The Black Hole, The Dark Crystal, Time Bandits, and Flash Gordon. The films were all tons of fun. None of them were meant to be masterpieces. Most of the time I saw films only once and had to live with them in my mind's memory for years on end with no possibility of re-watching them. Many films just came and went and no one kicking up much fuss. The NYT Janet Maslin review back in 1982 was not kind to the original but now the current review claims Tron Legacy did not live up to the original.  How is this possible? The incongruous reviews are because those involved in the reviewing process cared little then and care even less now. They know, somewhere because perhaps someone told them, that a group of people exists that hold the original in high regard. They write the new review, possibly after scanning the DVD at high speed or watching it once to sound like they know what the hell they are talking about but in the end they simply do not care. They probably do not even like science fiction. And even if they do they are too old, too cynical, too job oriented to just sit back and have some fun.Fast forward from the original crappy reviews almost 30 years and now the sequel to Tron is out and the reviews are claiming Tron Legacy is nothing like the original, not nearly as good. Never mind the fact that no one cared for the original even when it came out and were it not for the VHS, Laserdisc, DVD fan base all these years this sequel would not even exist. The original was a simple portal film where a dude goes into a computer to stop an evil computer program from taking over the world. The original could easily be criticized with the same sword many are wielding on the new one today. Seriously though, all faults the original may and do have are all forgiven because real fans love these old films anyway despite any flaws. The flaws give them charm. It was a B film that some people loved over time. It reminds me of childhood, of the 80s, of videogames, of the beginnings of the personal computer that has since become ubiquitous to all. They are charming and fun and remind us of our childhood. We like the hokey plot and don't care to over analyze any flawed logic. This is art, not some logical mind game.  Now 28 years later reviewers who could care less for the original are holding it up as some pillar when they do not even know what they are writing about.Just the very fact that a sequel is out is amazing to me. The Thing was a flop the very same year (1982) as Tron and I did not even see that film till years later. Now that too will get a prequel and some pseudo highbrow at the NYT will review it as if the original is some old fine wine they have loved and cherished forever. I love the original Tron and I can tell you even I did not care about it much when it came out. The way the reviewers are panning the new film makes it seem as if everyone loved the original and it was some smash hit. It wasn't. I did not care much till years later. Even schlock fun cinema today is approached by everyone as if it needs to be the height of storytelling as if ever story man has ever told has led up to Tron Legacy and anything less than God like perfection is garbage. First of all many have simply grown up too much in order to even enjoy good old clean visually excitable cinema. Second, if any of you go and watch Tron legacy with a 10 year old I dare you to tell them it was lame, and then explain why. I double dog dare you. And if you do, you'll have Scroodge-McGrinch written all over your face, and you'll have shut the bright happy wide eyes of some cool kid. The simple fact is that were this the film that came out 28 years ago with the SFX of the time and the original Tron were created today with modern SFX as a prequel all the same criticisms would be written of it.When I got Tron on laserdisc years ago I put the disc in, cranked up the volume, and jumped to the light cycle scene. No one used to give a hoot about this film but a hand full of us nerds. Now everyone is suddenly a connoisseur of the original when 1/2 of them are not even old enough to have been there to generate the cult status it now has that let this sequel become possible. No one was there writing dozens of big articles on the failure of the first film because back then cinema like this mattered less to the populace as a whole and more to the individual.  It's ironic that a film that flopped in the 80s gets a sequel 30 years later that is considered not as poignant and heartfelt as the original. Get over yourselves everyone and do me a favor, unless you owned the Laserdisc of Tron stop yammering that this one was no good. It was just as good if not better. And after waiting 28 years and sitting in the theater watching it with my wide-eyed 9 year old son who kept giving me the thumbs up every 5 minutes I can tell you it was well worth the wait.
summary: Great film if you are not cynical and jaded and hate everything

reviewText: Is it wrong of me to prefer logic over spectacle? Did I miss the point when I left "Tron: Legacy" feeling it was a monumental failure as a story? If I'm to continue with this review, I must first make it clear that I don't see the "Tron" films in the same way a lot of people do. I don't believe they deserve praise simply for their innovative special effects; I personally require an engaging plot, character development, and the sense that it's operating under a heightened but nonetheless understandable set of rules. In other words, I like a good sci-fi/fantasy film, but not when all effort is put into visuals and absolutely nothing is put into the screenplay. If that makes me a prude who wouldn't know a cool movie even if it came up and bit me, feel free to stop reading and start searching the web for a more enthusiastic review.Just like its 1982 predecessor, watching "Tron: Legacy" is a little like watching a demo reel from the visual effects department - all flash and bang but no substance. It makes not the slightest effort to be plausible or consistent, it freely glosses over glaring technicalities, the dialogue is unbelievably awkward, and the performances are wasted on characters with no depth. The plot is convoluted and impenetrable, and it seems the more it tries to explain, the less sense it makes. The entire concept of people living inside a computer is a logistical nightmare, but if I start rattling off a list, I fear I might not be able to stop. Its greatest offense is not having any audience in mind other than the original film's fan base, which, when you think about, hardly seems big enough to have warranted a sequel in the first place.I will admit that the film is a dazzling sight to behold. I was especially impressed with work done on the character of Clu, a hacking program; he was designed to look exactly like his creator, Kevin Flynn, but since people age and computer programs do not, it was necessary to digitally reconstruct the face of Jeff Bridges as it appeared over twenty years ago. The results are uncannily convincing. With just a little more development, we may someday see digital recreations of bygone Hollywood icons and not notice a difference. Imagine it - Humphrey Bogart acting alongside Ingrid Bergman in a sequel to "Casablanca."Since the events of the first film, Flynn got married, had a son, became a widower, and was promoted to CEO of a computer corporation called ENCOM International. He disappeared in 1989, leaving behind his son, Sam, and vague promises of a cutting edge digital revolution, one he claimed would forever change science, medicine, and religion. The story begins twenty years later, when a now twenty-seven-year-old Sam (Garrett Hedlund) breaks into ENCOM headquarters, distributes their newest operating system over the internet for free, uploads a virus into their mainframe, and escapes by jumping off the rooftop and releasing a parachute he just happened to have stowed away on his person. After his arrest and release, Sam is approached by ENCOM's consultant and Flynn's old friend Alan Bradley (Bruce Boxleitner), who says he received a page from Flynn's office, the number of which has been disconnected for twenty years. So help me God, the man is still using a pager.Upon entering his father's abandoned arcade, Sam discovers a secret room with a miraculously functional computer and a fully operational laser; with a few careless strokes of the keyboard, Sam is zapped with light and transported into the computer world, known as the Grid. We then witness must have been an homage to the sepia-tone-to-Technicolor transition shown in "The Wizard of Oz"; the film shifts from 2D to 3D, which is a new one on me. Sam is immediately captured by electronically-voiced guards in black suits with glowing orange stripes. After being stripped of his earthly clothes, fitted with a black suit with glowing blue stripes, and linked with a memory-storing disc that doubles as a Frisbee, he's pitted against Flynn's program, Clu (Jeff Bridges), who has since turned evil. He's then forced to participate in games of survival, including a race on digital motorcycles that trail light behind them. He's rescued by a program named Quorra (Olivia Wilde) and driven away from the city into the surrounding mountains. Mountains. In a computer grid. And there are clouds in the sky, too.I will now stop describing the plot and move on to some of the little things that drove me mad. There's a house stocked with furniture, physical paper books, and food. I must assume it's not some digital replication, for Sam is able to eat it without a problem. There's a club high atop a sky rise in the heart of the computer city, where a program played by Michael Sheen struts around with a cane and speaks like a Dr. Frank N. Furter wannabe. There's an ending which begs the question of how anything created in a computer could ever exist in the physical human world. After all, it's all just a bunch of immaterial zeros and ones. The fact that I'm fixated on this when I'm supposed to be enjoying myself should tell you everything you need to know. "Tron: Legacy" is a horrendous miscalculation, one of the least understandable films to come along in quite some time.
summary: This Movie Needs a System Reboot

reviewText: This sequel is a total disaster. Joseph Kosinski cannot direct actors or craft anything but the most cliched of scenes, and even his eye for visual effects lacks discipline; shots are loaded with egregious lightning flashes, poor use of particle effects, and a certain monomania in all aspects of audio / visual design. I actually think there are a few decent ideas in the script (Clu turning evil, Boxleitner's cameo, the Lightcycle course), but all are mangled by dreadful execution. Then we have "Zen Master" Kevin Flynn, evil Dillinger Jr., computer vixens prancing around in platform heels and inch-thick eye shadow, "2001" rip-off furniture, going back to the arcade (where there's a Tron game!), a motorcycle-riding jock as son of Flynn... it's all just beyond hokey.For all of the film's technical prowess, it does not hold a candle to its predecessor from nearly 30 years earlier even as eye candy. The kitchen sink production design deviates tremendously from the stark, haunting grid envisioned by Syd Mead and Moebius; Kosinski's world looks more like a ride at the Luxor Hotel (Fireworks... really?). Gone too is Wendy Carlos, replaced by the danceclub beats of Daft Punk... which are a bit of a mixed bag. It makes the whole thing feel a bit like being at a late-90s rave, and maybe that was the idea. Unfortunately for stock ticker DIS this sexed-up/dumbed-down approach did not translate into titanic revenues; this film grossed less than half of either The Dark Knight or Avatar worldwide.The original Tron was not a perfect film, but its spirit and originality, its conception of the burgeoning world of computers helped define an era, and lived up to Walt Disney's dream of breaking new ground with his company's films. The destruction of the MCP, its bizarre worlds and charming interludes (e.g. with the byte), along with some genuine creepiness earned Tron a solid place not only in the Disney canon, but I think it fares quite well alongside many classic Sci-Fi films like "Things To Come". I doubt that many people will be saying the same about this preposterous sequel.

reviewText: TRON: Legacy has been one of the most promoted films of the year. With a monstrous budget (around $200 million) and reports saying that Disney is worried that the film isn't tracking as well as they'd hoped, the initial thought process from these rumors is that the TRON sequel will open to a disappointing first place weekend much like the most recent Chronicles of Narnia film. As of this writing, I haven't gotten around to seeing the original film. I wanted to, but thanks to Disney it was pretty much pulled from every retail store imaginable whether you wanted to rent or purchase the film at least until next year. The urge to see TRON: Legacy didn't really sink in until around the time the third trailer was released. While the Daft Punk score has interested me from the beginning, TRON: Legacy just seemed like another overrated piece of eye candy that fanboys were getting excited about. The thing about first impressions though is that they always have the opportunity to be wrong.It's been twenty years since Kevin Flynn (Bridges) had made some miraculous breakthrough on what he only referred to as The Grid and mysteriously disappeared. Over the years without his father around, Sam (Hedlund) became reckless and spends his time sabotaging ENCOM, the company he inherited. Alan Bradley (Boxleitner), a friend of Kevin's who still works for ENCOM, pays a visit to Sam telling him that he's received a page from his father from a number that's been disconnected since his father's disappearance. Feeling doubtful and skeptical, Sam goes to investigate where the page originated from; Flynn's Arcade, his father's original workspace. It's here that Sam is transported to the digital world his father always talked about, The Grid. Sam is captured upon arrival and forced to compete in the games of the mysterious world. Sam crosses paths with a program named Clu, who looks exactly like his father did 20 years ago and wants nothing more than to prevent Kevin's escape from The Grid. Once the light cycles enter the equation and Sam's life seems to be in danger, Quorra (Wilde) makes her presence known. After saving Sam, Quorra takes him to meet his father. After the Flynn's reunite, they must come up with a plan that'll help get them all home without running into Clu along the way; a feat that is much more difficult and dangerous than it seems.The glorified TRON sequel is getting a lot of mixed reviews from most movie critics. The problem seems to lie within the way the film is written and its screenplay. To tell the truth, you don't see a movie like this for a great story alone. The special effects are the main attraction and boy, do they deliver. The way programs disintegrate when they're disposed of, the light cycle battles, airborne chases, and the many fight sequences in the film are just a small example of the dazzling display of some of the most exceptional and impressive special effects ever seen in a cinematic feature. As with most films that have been presented in 3D lately, the 3D effect probably isn't necessary to enjoy a film of this magnitude. It'll be just as entertaining if you save yourself the extra $4 and see it in a conventional theater.The writing didn't seem as bothersome as much as other reports say. It certainly wasn't the best, but it seemed like enough to add just the right amount of depth to TRON: Legacy and give it more of a background than most films revolving around spectacular special effects. There were a few lines that bothered me. The main one being when Alan first visits Sam and Sam says something about his father probably either being dead or chilling in Costa Rica...or both. Wait, what? It just gives you this Weekend at Bernie's flashback with Bernie being replaced with Kevin Flynn's limp carcass. Some of the lines Jeff Bridges muttered just made him seem way too much like The Dude from The Big Lebowski, which seems awesome but really has no place in the TRON universe. Saying things like, "Check this out," or, "Radical, man," followed by that stoner laugh of his really didn't help matters much. The weak points of the way the film is written are rectified with the way the film never lets your attention out of its chokehold. You'll be drawn to the screen the entire film; that's practically a guarantee. The right mindset for a film like this can make or break your opinion of the film. If you don't have inflated expectations and don't expect much more than impressive special effects, then you'll probably walk away pleasantly surprised. I actually had a similar mindset during Avatar, which seemed to also suffer/take advantage of groundbreaking special effects being more consuming than the story and had a similar result.The cast is about as developed as can be expected. The real star of the film is Garrett Hedlund, who does a pretty decent job of carrying the film and being generally astonished that not only was his father alive but the extraordinary world he always talked about actually existed. Jeff Bridges' performance isn't nearly as strong as his portrayal of Rooster Cogburn in True Grit, but he does have his moments. He seems to shine during his reunion with Hedlund and his strongest scenes are with Hedlund alone while being rather flat the rest of the time. Olivia Wilde's Quorra is interesting, as well. There's an intriguing twist to her character, but her fascination and curiosity revolving around the world Sam is from is what gives her character heart. Michael Sheen did seem a bit too over the top at times as Castor, but that may have been the point. The biggest surprise was seeing Cillian Murphy cameo. Given his strong outings in films like Sunshine, Peacock, and Inception, it just left me wanting to see more of his character in future installments assuming this film does well enough to warrant a sequel (or sequels).TRON: Legacy is certainly the special effects extravaganza it's been made out to be all year. Its fantastic effects certify the sequel as being the most visually appealing film of the year. While the writing of the film isn't quite as polished as the special effects, there certainly seems to be a good enough balance to keep the film afloat and deliver an extremely entertaining way to kill two hours. As far as eye candy goes, TRON: Legacy is an incredible and all around awesome experience.
summary: The most visually appealing film of 2010

reviewText: 28 years, 161 days later, Tron's legacy lives on. Joe Kosinkski's understated long-awaited sequel to Steven Lisberger's game changing electronic mythos is a visual triumph, a world unlike anything we've ever seen before, transforming the iconography of its predecessor into an awesome 3D spectacle, but it is an imperfect world, its breathtaking three dimensions propped upon the two dimensional pillars of its problematic plot and one that would be looked upon with the consternation of its biggest adversary who, ironically, is the one who nearly completely undermines and very nearly derezzes it... Clu... and the guy doesn't dig imperfection.The film's biggest special effect is also its biggest failure. The technology that I had hoped would be the promise of taking Tron once again to a new revolutionary cinematic level and breaking new technical ground in much the same way as the original film had ushered in a new era at the dawn of the digital filmmaking frontier demonstrates that we still have quite a ways to go before digital actors can convincingly look indistinguishable from real human performers and reinforces the theory of the "Uncanny Valley" in robotics that says the closer we get to making artificial constructs look human the more we can identify their subtle inhuman imperfections. The CGI animation used to make Jeff Bridges look 20 years younger more closely resemble the animated cut-scenes from its video game counterpartTRON: Evolution. Comparing it to how he looks in other earlier films of his career likeStarmanit's obvious that Bridges did not look quite like his poorly rendered doppleganger at that age. The eyes, the brows, the cheekbones, and the mouth have an unconvincing artificiality about them that betrays the illusion and his aged voice also belies the effect. In a creepy sort of way it almost works for the character within the context of the story because he is supposed to be an artificial construct and we can almost buy that he doesn't look quite like a real human being, but during the film's opening scenes when we see Bridges in flashback playing younger Kevin Flynn telling bedtime stories to his son, Sam, it robs the moment between a father and his son of its already forced sincerity and dehumanizes it in a cold and unsettling way.The plot is almost video-game like in its objective as the competing faction of Clu's militaristic forces must obtain elder Flynn's identity disc which is a master key to unlock the door to our world so that he and his army can take it over. It is never convincingly explained how exactly virtual programs existing in the digital world can somehow manifest themselves into tangible living matter in our physical world with Flynn's disc like a magician pulling a rabbit out of an ethereal hat, just as it does not attempt to explain why a User like Sam can bleed in its digital realm other than the fact he is simply a User and "he's different," nor does it attempt to explain how Kevin Flynn has aged 20 years trapped in his digital confinement when theoretically he shouldn't have physically aged at all as a digital avatar of himself. Narratively it misses those opportunities to explore such metaphysical questions as it so masterfully eluded to in the film's promising test trailer shown at Comic Con the way that the originalTronexplored such intriguing philosophical ideas around the religious beliefs of its programs and their creators. Tron Legacy's most astonishing revelation delivered by Alan when he tells Sam that his father was about to change science, medicine and religion in such a profound way is simply thrown away in a single line of expository dialogue. We never learn the real reason why Flynn created this world in the first place other than the fact that it was far out biodigital jazz, man.Once again Jeff Bridges is the chemistry that holds the foundations of the Troniverse together solely with his strength and conviction of his performance as zen guru cyber-Jesus Flynn to his Judas megalomaniacal alter-ego Clu in some sort of virtual yin and yang. Garret Hedlund is surprisingly likeable as his son, Sam. Thankfully, he's no wooden Hayden Christiansen (although he would have made a much better Anakin Skywalker) and plays the cliched angst-ridden rebellious youth with convincingly noble admiration. Reciprocally, Olivia Wilde plays the character of Quorra with a truthful childlike innocence and wonder that demonstrates she has more to offer as an actress than just luscious fanboy eyecandy. Michael Sheen livens the film as Castor with his jestly rendition of David Bowie circa glam rock era Ziggy Stardust. And once again Bruce Boxleitner returns as Alan Bradley aka Tron... sort of. After all it's called TRON Legacy, right? Though, like the first film, the story is centered around Flynn's character and his legacy of which Tron is merely incidental to. The enigmatic character of Rinzler is Clu's henchman, one part Darth Maul wielding two discs, and one part Boba Fett as a mysterious tracker whose helmeted identity is concealed and it doesn't take half a nerd to figure out who he is.As a 3D film Tron Legacy's illuminated electronic visuals perfectly lends itself to creating brightly rendered 3D images which has been the pitfall of all other 3D films. Tron Legacy is by far the real Avatar. It makes the world of Pandora look like a cartoon by comparison. The Grid is a place I would want to visit again because it is unlike anything seen in our world or any other. The brilliantly 3D rendered Disney logo showcasing the Magic Kingdom "Tronified" is appropriately memorable for setting the tone of the film which is then 2D until Sam is transported into Tron's colorful three dimensional illuminated world like Dorothy in theThe Wizard of Oz. As a first-time director Joe Kosinski proves that he has the technical prowess to design a fully immersive world much like Ridley Scott did with Alien and Blade Runner but his weakness is marshaling a bullet-proof script equally as flawless to support it, but then again the original Tron, to be fair, didn't necessarily have a solid script to support it either so in that sense they are both equally as flawed and both equally as visually stunning.As a fan of the original Tron I am torn. Part of me is protective of its mythos and at the same time heartbroken that what was once a unique, groundbreaking film has now been rendered obsolete by its own sequel that has taken the technology and improved upon it in nearly every visual way. The Lightcycle and Disc Wars sequences, for example, are spectacularly exhilarating and render the graphics in the original film relics of the Atari age by comparison and why Disney has wisely kept the original Tron film hidden away in its vaults and hasn't released it on blu-ray yet to avoid the inevitably unfair comparisons. Fortunately as a sequel it delivers without the bitter disappointment of sequels like Star Wars or Indiana Jones. It's no Phantom Menace or Crystal Skull, thank God. If it performs well there will no doubt be more Tron films that confident Disney has stated they already have in development along with an animated TV show Tron Uprising and will hopefully include the participation of Jeff Bridges and Bruce Boxleitner to make them work. Without them, it wouldn't be a Tron film at all. Tron lives. He fights for the Users.END OF LINE

reviewText: To me, Tron legacy represents the adult realization that just because you liked something as a child doesn't mean it will hold up when you're an adult. Case in point; Tron, a mediocre B movie from the early 80s which had some cool special effects though in a bad way even by 80s standards. But the idea was novel; a man is trapped in a video game. It was a boring film, but people liked it, mainly because they were children and didn't know any better.Fast forward something like twenty-eight years to Tron Legacy. Great potential. I admit, I was blown away by the trailer. The notion of Jeff Bridges' son following him into the digital world to find/rescue him was outstanding. The thought of how the digital world has developed a-la the internet kept my mind racing.Truth be told, the movie was boring. It was great to see 'The Dude,' in the digital world battling a younger version of himself. And the effects were outstanding. But you'd think after twenty-eight years they'd have come up with some kind of a plot. Don't get me wrong Tron Legacy has a lot of bells and whistles. Not to mention eye candy.But seriously, the bad guys can't find the dude who's living by himself on a mountain within eye sight of the city? He's the only one on the mountain. You can see a light coming from his house! Nobody ever asked; I wonder who lives up there?The Matrix covered this ground better.When I hear people raving about how great it was, it reminds me of all those guys back in 97 coming out of 'The Phantom Menace,' Light Sabers in hand, for the tenth time saying things like, 'This one just sets things up.' And 'George will come out swinging with the next one. You'll see.'Just my opinion.By David Feeney, AuthorTerror On The High Seas
summary: Twenty-eight years, you'd think they'd come up with a better plot

reviewText: If you liked the original Tron film, then I have no doubt you'll love this film. The film has the same feel and overall-same basic plot progression. The special effects are mostly (I'll discuss why "mostly" later) incredible and the visual direction of the film is very stunning. They did an excellent job of updating everything from the first film into a stylized futuristic environment that blows us away visually.Tron: Legacy is about Sam Flynn, Kevin Flynn's son, as he searches the computer world for his father who mysteriously disappeared 20 years earlier.This is a fun film to watch and is just really stunning visually. The special effects are all awesome minus one thing - a computer-enhanced younger Jeff Bridges. For the first half of the movie, you may not even realize that he is computer-enhanced. But the character seems to become more and more unrealistic and fake looking as the movie continues. By the end, it is way too obvious that the young Bridges is CG-affected. It is especially noticeable when he talks. It reminds me of The Mummy Returns when you first see the Scorpion King monster near the end of the film - there's all this build up and then you see the monster and you think, "He looks like a plastic Ken doll placed on a prehistoric dino-toy body." Disappointing.There were also a lot of loopholes and unanswered questions brought up by the film:*Spoiler Alert*What was the point of the two spheres CLU was using during the disc battle. It seemed that he was using them to control TRON, but they never showed up again. Why?Why did TRON suddenly turn good in the end? What happened that caused this sudden loyalty change?What happens to a program when they enter the human world? Does their body become human? How can a program exist in this world without being human?*End Spoiler Alert*And other questions. Overall, the film was a fun watch and a great update of the original Tron film. Worth seeing at least once.[...]

reviewText: What can I say? This movie gives you exactly what you're looking for. It has perfect action, perfect style, and perfect characters. Some may complain of its "boring" or "weak" plot, but for me... it's every action/adventure-lover's dream come true. The light bike scene is the hands-down best action scene this year. Apart from the action, the score of this movie really gives it life. Each of the tracks fit perfectly to the scene and gave me this weightless feeling that is unmatchable. So if you're looking for a movie to be amazed by its script and plot, rent The Social Network or Inception. But if you're looking for an expertly-crafted sci-fi adventure filled with spectacle and wonder, rent (buy) TRON: Legacy.The Visuals: Absolutely Ground-breaking. Never before has computer animation felt so life-like; so realistic yet imaginative. The movie alone features the best visuals (in my opinion) available today. The Blu-ray transfer is the best I have ever seen. The best element is definitely the shifting aspect ratio which gives you an awesome feel every time it changes to full screen. Apart from that, the colors are perfect, the detail is so crisp without being overblown, and the blacks are astounding, so smooth and glossy that it makes you believe you are actually in the movie. If you are looking for a demo disk, look no further. Pop in TRON: Legacy and let your jaw-drop.Now for the Audio: As if the visuals could be matched? The 7.1 surround sound is deafening: in a good way. Scratch that: in a GREAT way. This is absolutely the best audio I've ever heard. Daft Punk's perfect soundtrack will ignite your speakers, and every tiny sound effect will be present in your house. Sounds are crisp and clear, and action sequences will shake your house. If you had any expectations for the audio , you might as well drop them now, because TRON: Legacy shatters them all.The extras: Many have been complaining about these, but really I am quite satisfied. Sure, there could have been more. But there are certain factors that bring up the score for me. For starters, the three featurettes about the movie were really well done; short but sweet. The "Flynn Lives" extra was spectacular, providing a great story for fans of the movie: one that gave you hope for a third movie. Finally, what made the disc for me was the incredible main menu: which is the best I have ever seen: Amazing!Finally, the TRON: Legacy Blu-ray disc was everything I would have hoped it to be. Perfect quality to a near-perfect movie with a great amount of extras. I really recommend that you get this Blu-ray because it is one of the best available. The movie is the perfect blockbuster that is backed up with amazing visuals and audio. The disc will be playing in my PS3 for a long time to come. In terms of action and adventure, forget Avatar and buy TRON: Legacy as soon as possible!
summary: A Cinematic Journey into Visual and Audio Perfection

reviewText: TRON: LEGACY - just my two cents - was a fairly cool film. I can't say it was on par with the original (see my review). There has been too much innovation in a short span, and TRON: LEGACY just does not really innovate. In fact, it looked like some odd entry in the STAR WARS franchise.In brief, old Flynn (Jeff Bridges) is lost in cyberspace again - this time to be rescued by his son Sam (a drop-dead gorgeous Garrett Hedlund, BIG upcoming star for this young hunk). While I liked the nods at the original TRON, and loved seeing the set of Flynn's old 1980s arcade, it was all too familiar and a tad boring. The music, desperately trying to grasp a pinch of the old 1980s electronic madness, just fell flat.And what is up with Michael Sheen appearing in weirdo cameos every time I turn around ... is he that strapped for cash?Jeff Bridges is very good in this, I must say. Though his Zen-like existence in cyberspace could have been turned into a zonked-out joke, it actually works. Admittedly, the first scene with the real Flynn gives chills. He looks as if the cyberspace life has pushed him toward enlightenment.Now back to my present focus, which is Garrett Hedlund. This kid (he says he's 27 in the film) is an amazing moving sculpture. His sweet-but-tough Swedish countenance and amazing body is electrifying enough to carry any film. reviewText: I'm really not sure how well this movie works if Tron isn't a part of your childhood. In its day Tron was something unique. reviewText: When the original Tron came out in 1982, I was a rabid fan. The idea of a computer outsmarting its users and reaching global domination was a popular theme for the time, a la Wargames. You were introduced to five characters whose lives were intertwined with one another, and who also possessed counterparts in the digital realm.The remake bears no resemblance to the original. As with many movies nowadays, the movie centers around action, not plot and charater development. We are barely introduced to the main character before he pulls a ridiculous stunt on a company he himself owns. From there, we see a familiar face in Alan Bradley, but he is given maybe twenty minutes of screen time throughout the whole movie. Sam goes to his father's arcade, enters a code, and is transported to the digital realm. There, without even being taken to a holding cell, he is placed in the 'games', until his identity as a user is discovered by none other than Tron (another actor with a full mask, with a voice over by Bruce Boxleitner). He is then introduced to Clu, who seeks to destroy him via another confrontation, this time on light cycles. As Sam is about to be killed, he is rescued By Quorra, played by Olivia Wilde, his father's 'apprentice'. A father and son reunion ensues, followed by a race to beat Clu to the I/O tower.This movie was made, as another reviewer said, to capitalize on the short attention spans of the younger generation. The characters (with the exception of Jeff Bridges and a very short appearance by Bruce Boxleitner) are the only redeeming things in this movie. The computer circutry has been downplayed in favor of a streamlined, flashy look. Here, instead of a couple of characters joining forces in a common goal, we have the all too common father-son reunion, and the confusion and anger that follows. Hot chicks in latex abound, there are enough strobe lights to give a normal person an epileptic attack, and Tron has been reduced to a character who does nothing but make short appearances.Good visual movie, but there's no way in hell it will stand up to repeated viewings. It just doesn't have anything deeper than sex appeal and flash. No substance. One star for Jeff Bridges.

Kevin Flynn (big-time game developer and protagonist of the first film) has gone missing, leaving his son, Sam, to fend for himself. Sam eventually finds the Grid, a digital world his father had created many years ago. Here he finds his dad and faces a new enemy, Clu, who is a digital version of Kevin Flynn. Now Sam, Kevin, and a program called Quorra must now race to the portal if they are ever to escape the Grid. Though there are quite a few twist and turns in the movie, but the story itself is controversial. Many found the plot to be confusing. I personally didn't. I did like the story and definitely appreciated that there was one as opposed to it being an action flick with absolutely no story to it. The only thing I really would have changed is that I would have had more Tron in it, being as he's sort of the title character.Though the story is good, what really makes the movie great is its presentation. I would normally say that it is the special effects, for obvious reasons, but I have to be more broad, because the music is just as good. Daft Punk writes and performs the music to this film and their music is brilliant. It's very techno and suits the film perfectly. In terms of special effects, if you've watched any of the trailers, you know why they're great. reviewText: It's one of those funny myths of Hollywood.  The myth that the original Tron was a total failure and people didn't really get it.Well, that's half true.  People didn't really get it at all.  However, the part about it being a total failure wasn't true.  It grossed about $70 million with a cost of $17 million.  That was with very stiff competition like E.T. and others.  I think the fact that it didn't reach $100 million made someone at Disney float the rumor that it was some sort of bomb.Therefore, no sequel was forthcoming.  Perhaps ever.But over the better part of 30 years, it has become a classic.  And people have been wanting a sequel for a very long time.  In late 2010, they got their wish:  Tron Legacy.The film takes place in modern times, 27 years after the original.  Kevin Flynn (played in the original and in Legacy by Jeff Bridges) had the key to the next step in human evolution.  But, in 1989, before he can tell anyone the details, he mysteriously disappears, leaving behind a son with no mother or father.Flash forward to now.  That son, Sam Flynn, is a major shareholder in Encom, his dad's company, but seems to have little interest in being an executive.  He does love making the other execs nervous by committing a series of practical jokes at the company's expense, such as sabotaging Encom's new operating system by releasing it online for free before it can be put online for sale.But a mysterious page from Flynn's Arcade, closed for 20 years, indicates that his father is alive and well.  And Sam must find out what happened.The critics have been generally very lukewarm about this film.  My take is that it is a film that tries to straddle the fine line between kids fare and adults fare, with mixed results.  There's no denying that the special effects are pretty awesome and it captures the spirit of the original very well, albeit with a modern sensibility.  But, sometimes the performances by the cast, with some exceptions, are a little wooden and could use a bit more of a sense of humor.  They take it a bit too seriously.I think Jeff Bridges provides most of the humor and wit, Flynn being a bit of a ideological hippy, but he kind of overdoes it.  He does provide a great bad guy in his other role as Clu, the power hungry computer alter ego of Flynn's.Garrett Hedlund, who plays Sam, has the tendency to grunt and mumble his lines.  He's likable enough, but his enunciation skills could use some work.  He tries to talk like Clint Eastwood and it doesn't really work for him.Olivia Wilde, who plays Quorra, the video game warrior with a potentially world changing secret, is nice and she has the physicality to do the role, but even she is a bit plastic.  However, she has the ability and talent to improve in future movies.The highlight is Zeus, played by Michael Sheen, who provides the animated camp of David Bowie and Tim Curry.  But his screen time is rather short.  However, judging from his interviews, he didn't seem to mind that much.  He's been a fan of the original since he was a kid and loved being on the same set with Jeff Bridges.The Blu-Ray is awesome, as usual, with a 7.1 mix and razor sharp picture.  The switching between aspect ratios during the film is something new to me and I question its necessity, but it doesn't affect the quality of the disk.  And I do love the short film Flynn Lives (an epilogue, if you will), marking the return of a fan favorite from the first film (although he's not in Legacy).My verdict:  It's a promising re-launch and I look forward to future movies that can build upon this one and do a better job.End of line.

reviewText: Very decent sequel to the original Tron. I got goose bumps when I watched this in the theater.  It's been a long time coming but finally a sequel was done.Tron Legacy is a visually sound movie experience.  The 200 million dollar budget over the movie definitely shows on screen.  The incredible musical score by Daft Punk fits the film PERFECTLY and it definitely felt like this was taken right after the original TRON.Story: Kevin Flynn, the hero from the original movie, took over Encom but then mysteriously vanished. Sam's gets an s.o. s from Flynn's old arcade house. He gets there then he gets thrown back into the digital world of Tron (just like Flynn did in the original movie). Sam has to fight in the games of the grid like his father did all the while trying to get to his father, so the two can find a way out of the grid. Kevin it turns out was betrayed by his program, Clu, who has decided to take over the whole grid killing any programs and anomalies that threaten him.I read a couple of the critiques about the film with regards to the story, and the critics do have some valid points. The story told is pretty simple, and could have been reworked a bit more to  take full advantage of all the elements from the original movie including the actual character of Tron/ Alan Bradley  (Bruce Boxleitner) whose inexplicably reduced to a minor role....However, with that said, the writers didn't lose sight of the main character of Kevin Flynn who was the main character of the original movie. Jeff Bridges hasn't played the role in more than twenty eight years, but as the great actor he is, easily starts out where he left in the original and takes the character into another direction. Kevin Flynn is now older and as such is a wiser,  darker,  more mysterious character, not the same nave guy he was in the first movie.Joseph Kosinki's directorial style is good. He throws a lot of references to the original movie and uses a couple of comedy bits, but the movie for the most part has a dark and futuristic look that gives fans a good feel of where exactly the Tron universe has evolved too since the last movie.The movie  is definitely a visual spectacle for the eyes. Everything has been upgraded from the original, and you definitely do get the realism like the original that this guy has been sucked into the movie. The light cycles have been upgraded, and you see programs disassembled and destroyed In more graphic fashion than in the original movie. We also get the cool hand to hand disc battles that were in the original with the exception now that the fights borrow a lot from motion style of fighting. There are added new gadgets like the light jets and light cars.There's also besides the visual feats as mentioned an incredible music score by French musicians Daft Punk (who have a small cameo in the movie as a couple of digital Dj's). Daft Punk's score is definitely another element that really made the movie quite an experience.The performances in the movie are good.  As talked about Jeff Bridges as Kevin Flynn has grown from the original movie. Garrett Hedlund as Sam Flynn does his role well as the estranged son here. Studios gave the director a mighty big budget to work with, and he took advantage of it. It's true the script and story could have been better but as far as what happens to the main character of Kevin Flynn, they did answer a lot of questions that we wanted to know since the first movie and introduced a couple of new ones for possible sequels. If there are plans for further entries in the franchise then they must include a deeper story that takes more advantage of the characters from the original including Tron.  As far as this movie goes,  I think they got right what they were supposed to do which is get news fans interested in the franchise, and get older dedicated fans of  the original something to look back on.

reviewText: Whenever you produce a remake, sequel, or otherwise related movie to an old classic, comparisons are inevitable. Like many of its kind, Tron Legacy can feel less impressive next to the original, but that doesn't mean it's a bad film in its own right.Visually, Legacy channels much of the spirit of the original film with fantastic updated designs to the landscape, sets, and vehicles present in the film. However, certain other elements have been streamlined, mostly notably the costumes. Whereas in the first film programs would often be seen wearing rather bizarre costumes that formed odd shapes and unique silhouettes filled with complex, circuit-board like design patterns. In this film, everybody wears the same generic body suit with a few conservative light patterns. The handful of characters you see that look different, have a more generic cyber-punk look to them such as loose clothing with basic trim patterns. Often when you see the actors interacting with each other, it looks more like a new matrix movie or a lost star wars episode then Tron.Story wise while the original film was a wide-arc adventure focusing on the discovery of this new fantasy world. The new film is instead a character-driven story about Sam Flynn, the son of Kevin Flynn from the first film. Pretty much the entire film is told from his perspective, with plenty of drama, romance, and action. As a character development piece it is pretty good, but it missed out on a great deal of potential. `The Grid' is portrayed more as just another alternate dimension rather then being a world inside our computer software, as all the ties that related it to real electronics are gone. Aside from the occasional reference to users and programs, there's no more bits, no more data streams, the internet is never even mentioned. I was personally hoping to see how the new world created in Tron would've evolved over the years, as technology has evolved so far and so fast. Instead we got the story of Sam Flynn. Again, they could've removed the few references to the world established in the first Tron and called it a new Matrix film, and you wouldn't know the difference.On the other hand, the action sequences in this film are fantastic. The creative team took full advantage of the advanced technology available today and the deep pockets that Disney has. Deadly Discs is given a multiplayer tournament setup, the light bikes race across multiple levels, and the aerial battle at the end is just fantastic!As far as the extras on this blue ray package, they are all well worth it. Tron Legacy is available in a large number of packages, and I'd strongly advise consumers to take the time to compare and contrast before making their final decision. Do you really need three versions of this film? One on DVD, one on Blue Ray, and on for 3D? Sounds pretty wasteful. And don't even think about the four or five disk sets, that just insane. Save yourself the cash and pick this up on a cheaper set like this one. You can't go wrong when you're saving this kind of money.
summary: Not quite Tron, but still a great film!

reviewText: Before I review Tron:  Legacy, I feel I should point out that I have little emotional connection to the original Tron film, a movie which I thought had a very unique idea, but was at the same time an average film that had a nifty visual style, but a plot that felt muddled with no real goal or purpose, and was mostly a showcase for the film's look.  Now, almost thirty years later, Tron has finally gotten a sequel that delivers pretty much more of the same, but adds an interesting dimension to this digital universe.Tron:  Legacy begins back in 1989.  Kevin Flynn, now a rich and wildly successful CEO of ENCOM International, talks with his son, Sam, about the Tron universe.  But like almost all happy families in films, things fall apart.  Kevin vanishes, and Sam grows up an unhappy, fatherless kid.  But one day, Kevin sends a page, and Sam heads to the old arcade his father frequented, and soon finds himself inside the Tron world, and finds himself involved in a plot that could introduce both worlds to each other...with disastrous consequences.At first glance, Tron delivers a mixed experience...the visuals, as to be expected, are incredible, full of sleek, shiny, yet dark technology that has fused to create a world of haunting, electronic beauty, full of dazzling black and neon that feels artificial, yet real at the same time, as if this place really exists in a world different from our own.  Yet, on the story level, Tron:  Legacy feels as muddled as it's predecessor.  The visuals and the world itself take the spotlight, and the script feels somewhat aimless, moving along without a greater theme or meaning (There is a subplot about life that spontaneously appears and could change humanity's perception on everything, but it doesn't really go anywhere), and when it's over, it feels somewhat empty.However, there is an unexpected surprise within the story...while Sam and Quorra are supposed to be the main characters, it's Kevin and Clu who steal the spotlight, as they share an almost religious relationship, with Kevin being God, and Clu being the devil, who started out good, but eventually sought to rule the Tron world.  The relationship between the two is fascinating and compelling to watch, and I really wish the movie had focused completely on the two of them, and the idea that the God of the Tron world has lost control of his creation, and now has to deal with the consequences.In the end, Tron: Legacy is a fun sequel.  Despite the weak story, it's fantastic visuals, fascinating relationship between Kevin and CLU (who is really a digitally de-aged Jeff Bridges, an effect pulled off very well), and great action moments help to make it a fun experience worth seeing.  It doesn't hit masterpiece status, but it gets pretty close, and in that aspect, it's a worthy successor to the original.
summary: A great graphical upgrade, but not much else

It was pretty ludicrous but Legacy really went further with some of the ridiculous elements as well as just some gaping holes.  This is Disney after all and they generally aren't known for tight stories, just stunning animation.  The biggest problem in the film I think is that the director is a professional architect.  What happens is the guy spent so much time focusing on set design that the world of Tron ends up being the principle character.  The actual actors are nothing but a vehicle to move you around from one impressive set piece to another.  Successful directors tend not to let their production elements dominate the story.Acting wise the film is ok I suppose.  Jeff Bridges is a great actor but I suspect that the CGI for his CLU character distracts you from his performance and his Kevin character is a bit too much Big Lebowski meets Obi Wan Konobi this time around.  (Granted the plot is a heavily borrowing from Star Wars)  The two youngsters in the film were passable largely because their roles were more physical than emotional.  Basically if they could move they were pushing the film.  I garner that both will gain sex symbol status from their respective fan clubs but to the older crowds they are pretty forgettable.One major gripe I tend to have is that there was very little attempts by the Director/writers to incorporate Tron/Rinzler in to the story more.  Frankly we rarely see Tron and even when he is on screen you don't even realize it.  Kind of silly.Overall I think Tron Legacy was a major visual and auditory success which will forever be plagued by a lousy story.  It's a fun mindless film to throw on once in a while but much of its appeal will be lost from it's translation from the theater to your TV.  Had the director not been so set oriented maybe he could have tightened up the script but alas, it's Disney...  Traditionalists will despise this, casual or new fans will find it enjoyable.  I suspect the films soundtrack will outlive the popularity of the film.

reviewText: After seeing this revision of a cult Disney Sci-Fi classic last Christmas, I couldn't wait for the DVD to come out.  In a time of never ending rumors circulating online about blockbuster film remakes because of a lack of great storytelling coming out of Hollywood, the time is just right for Walt Disney's TRON to finally journey into the 21st Century.  The 1982 Sci-Fi classic has been long overdue for a major upgrade and thanks to a visionary director, talented screenwriters, genius special effects artists and the wonders of 21st Century computer technology along with the many refined talents of an all star cast, comes a one of a kind digital spectacle more then twenty years in the making.The film takes place twenty years after the sudden disappearance of computer genius and Encom executive, Kevin Flynn (Jeff Bridges) and with his son Sam (Garrett Hedlund) struggling with a deep sense of personal loss and belonging in the present high tech digital age of technology, reluctantly takes it upon himself to reconnect with a long lost relic of his father's genius, an old arcade where he finds in his Dad's office an old computer that launches him into the unpredictable and unbelievable world of TRON.  Here, Sam has to match wits with highly skilled disc throwers, cunning opportunists and a notoriously dangerous replicate of a computer program of Kevin Flynn's design that runs amuck and starts a crusade against father and son as they fight to bring order and balance to the chaotic universe that has become the new world of TRON.  Fortunately, they are not only in their quest.  With the help of Quorra, the daring and charming heroine (Olivia Wilde) takes the lead as Sam's partner and protector throughout the adventure and along the way, the pair finds things out about themselves and their two different worlds that they could only discover together.  From there, the action and peril only builds as the film takes viewers on a ride where misadventures and surprises await the trio at every turn.The film's computer generated visual effects only serve to heighten the grandeur of the characters' environment.  With unique set designs, space age costumes and eerily mysterious weather patterns, all blend in seamlessly well with the film.  Visionary director, Joseph Kosinski, brings an original architectural approach to the futurist revamp of the TRON franchise, which is very appropriate for its time when you're introducing a long and forgotten cult classic to a new generation of movie goers who for the most part, thought "Avatar" was the coolest thing they had ever seen.  For me personally, I liked TRON: Legacy way better because of the storyline and the special bonds that develop between the main characters.  Jeff Bridges does a superb job serving as the anchor and guide to the new film and newcomers Garrett Hedlund and Olivia Wilde have excellent chemistry together on screen.  Garrett Hedlund plays the tender role of Sam perfectly and Olivia Wilde shows that Quorra can be loving, athletic and sexy all at the same time.I bought the DVD Blu-Ray pack for the sake of the added behind the scenes special features.  It would have been easier if they had released a two disc version of the new TRON movie on DVD like they did with the original 25th anniversary edition but that's beyond me.  Viewing the special features on Blu-Ray came with a few disappointments with occasional glitches here and there but other then that, the deleted scene of what happened after Sam's adventure and the behind the scenes featurettes about the mythology of the TRON universe were all very impressive.  It will be interesting to see what else Disney has in store for the TRON movie franchise, I guess we'll have to wait and see.
